I think the central reason behind the theory "rich people are mean" boils down to classism. People with more materials, resources and privileges don't need to be kind to just anyone, and can choose to dismiss people who are of a lower class than themselves as irrelevant and unimportant because they don't rely on them or strive to live like them. They have more opportunities, and they don't want to lose their power. In my experience, really wealthy people aren't outwardly mean, but if you get to know them a little more they pretty much are snobs, rude and inconsiderate. They dehumanize and dismiss those who are below them on the social class hierarchy. They only want to associate with others who have similar bank accounts as their own. They don't want increases in taxes, and when they "give back" they do so to make a show of their good character, not because they always treat others in egalitarian or considerate manners. Yet, they somehow make sure to keep their own kids from interacting with middle class kids who have single parents or attend public schools. Not all really wealthy people are the same in character, obviously. But in general, they are greedy, classist, uncaring and stick with their own kind.

Good video, however, I think you're confusing money and power (or perceived power). A persons empathy for others lowers when they are put in a supposedly powerful position. There is an interesting although controversial, study done in 1971 by Philip Zimbardo, where college students were assigned a roll of prisoner or guard. The "guards" knew that that the "prisoners" had done nothing wrong, yet they still proceeded to treat them with disrespect and punish them, so much so that some "prisoners" quit and the study was terminated after 6 days. Demonstrating how a perceived superiority over someone lowers you empathy. Some rich may view their money as a form of superiority, and therefore treat others with less with disrespect, however some rich may not. The same can be seen in the middle class, if someone sees themselves as superior, they mistreat those they deem less so.

TL;DR: Are rich people worse humans? No, wealth just happens to give people who are already jerks an outsized opportunity to advertise the fact that they are jerks.

The too long version:

It depends on how you define rich. People who have lots of money and consequently spend lots of money (the aforementioned Mercedes drivers, for example) are obviously quite concerned with image, status, and power. It would make sense that they aren't the nicest people around. If you primarily use your money to make yourself appear superior to others, that betrays an overall state of being that many, I think, would label as "jerk".

On the other hand, people who have lots of money but don't spend it all are another case entirely. Not only are these people generally wealthier (because they save their wealth rather than spend it), but they're also more difficult to label as rich. Imagine a multi-millionaire who lives in a nice, old ranch house in a middle-class part of town and who rides a bike everywhere. These people exist, and are in fact pretty common, but would people even know that they're rich? They could even be total jerks, but since no one has any reason to think they're rich, the title "rich jerk" doesn't get applied to them.

So I think the real factor here is how eager you are to use your wealth to show off to others. Not only are people who use wealth to project status or an attitude of superiority more likely to be labelled "jerks" due to their behavior, but they're also the most conspicuously wealthy. The wealthy people who live simply and keep to themselves just sort of fade into the background and no one even considers them in the equation.

1. The Car thing is just as likely about car horsepower- in fact, that’s one of the conclusions drawn from the original study. Also, cars are less likely to be tied to wealth than other high-ticket goods like homes and boats.

2. Rich people donate a lower portion of their income. They’re also taxed twice the percentage of income that poor people are, and their income is often way more tied up in investments and businesses. This could lead to both feeling like they do enough already for the country and not wanting to go through more legal hoops to donate extra.

3. Rich people fidget more and look at you less. Rich people also are often in high-stress, high importance jobs and are used to lots of people calling them for business reasons. Learned behavior and stress-induced anxiety are a thing.

I feel this video sends the wrong message. You mention that as you become more powerful (or rich) you lose empathy and “become more self centered”. While that may be true, it’s not because they suddenly loathe or feel better than others. But rather that when you become a leader, you are asked to care for a large number of people, objects, money, etc. and are forced to make decisions that may hurt an individual for the benefit of the whole. That’s why on average, less emotional, or detached personalities tend to be more successful leaders (and generally more liked and well respected too). Because they value the whole more than individuals. It’s not out of disrespect, but out of necessity to protect what is (or is perceived to be) the greater good. That’s why I feel it’s unfair to portray rich people as selfish or blind to other’s emotions. Obviously, there are rich people that are just jerks, but in most cases I would argue that there’s a bigger picture that often gets ignored in this discussion. Instead of focusing solely on the “what’s”, let’s also inquire the “why’s”

I think that the decrease in empathy from wealth comes due to the need to protect oneself from cognitive dissonance. When you gain wealth and time, your view of the world can broaden so when you see the extreme need for resources in the world around you, you have to somehow say that your resources couldnt help them and are rightfully yours. Personal accountability is at a climax during success (see fundamental attribution errors), and so the rich become less empathetic toward people with needs going unfulfilled. Of course, there's already 3,364 comments, so no one will ever read this. But I find it odd how you can publish a video proving rich people to be jerks, and also publish a video on how good looking people are only perceived as jerks. Now of course I have no scientific backing to prove my point, so I could be wrong. But I think that the reason rich people are perceived as jerks is similar to your are good looking people jerks video. We ignore rude, poor people, and we focus more on people that are rich. There are nice rich people and there are rude rich people, but rude rich people stick out more in our mind because of a subconscious envy. Especially in regards to wealth, having money puts a target on your back, because people who are less wealthy than you automatically assume you are a selfish person without even bothering to try and see past the "wealth hatred" filter.

There also tends to be a difference in philosophies or values between rich and poor people. Poor people tend to focus more on enjoying the present or following their passion, whereas rich people tend to focus more on preparing for the future. This difference in values causes a ton of misunderstanding, causing dislike or even bullying. Your point is validated in the "The Perfect Gooseys", where a janitor's kid is mercilessly bullied by rich kids, but keep in mind the same thing can happen to a smart kid who works to be successful in school but gets bullied by people that aren't working in school. I can attest to this first hand- I was bullied in school by people that hated me for being smart. One girl used to step on the back of my shoes in the hallway and throw books at me. Another group of people wouldn't let me play kickball with them, saying, "Sorry- we don't let nerds play." Some of those kids didn't make it to college, while I'm now in one of the top engineering programs in the nation. Now that I'm more successful than them, and because I will likely be wealthier than them in the future, does that make me the jerk?

Who you view as mean depends on your perspective. Since engineers end up with a salary that puts then in the top 10-20% of the nation's wealth, that means the other 80-90% of people are poorer than that person and more likely to view them as a jerk. I'm not saying I've never run into rude rich people. But overall in my life, the people who have been the meanest to me have been the people that had less success than me and hated me for it. If you have different values and a different perception of the world, it can be really hard to get along. But understanding that different in philosophy and why rich and poor people do what they do is the first step to getting along better.

I don't worry about money anymore and still have plenty of empathy for everyone who works so damn hard.  Because I remember when I looked at the amount on the gas pump and couldn't just buy whatever I need at the grocery store. I still feel like this is more pseudo-science than actual science backed more by a political agenda than real, authentic curiosity. True scientific analysis always makes you ask more questions and see more possibilities -- this video seemed more like telling you what to think versus *how*. I do agree, there is a reason for the stereotype. Money creates a form of power that, in some way, great or small, will alter the way a person thinks and views themselves, and there is definitely a percentage of wealthy people who use it for selfish and destructive means.

However, in my opinion, the problem is not with the money alone, but human nature. Money, in spite of its wonderful and terrible pedigree, is in and of itself an inanimate, neutral object. It's dependent upon how the person uses it. Some people use it for good, others use it for bad. Some use it to feed the homeless and pay for medical expenses incurred by poor children who have cancer, others use it to build bombs and later drop them on other countries.

While the video was fun and creative, and you guys genuinely seem like good fun people, my one caveat to the video would be that wealth can also be used for good, and can be used to incentivize people with really big ideas that could make society a better place (think Elon Musk). Giving people the impression that accumulating wealth will automatically make you an asshole, while fun (because, hey, who doesn't like to see the temple topple every now and then, right?) is also misleading, similar to the old-time rumor that giving a five dollar bill to a homeless person will automatically make them run for the liquor store or a drug dealer. Are there those who fit the profile? Sadly, yes. But you're also inadvertently squashing the exceptions to the rule who, believe it or not, could actually use it for good.

These are just my two cents and should be taken with a grain of salt, but that's just my opinion.

Other than that, I give you props for making enjoyable content. Keep it up, and continue to have fun with what you do.

Uh, when you make less than $25,000 in America, not only do you not pay taxes -- your effective tax rate is, on average, negative. Whereas, if you make $100,000, your effective tax rate leads to a tax bill that is at least $13,000, or 13% of your income.

I don't have a problem with this. Right out of college, my salary was about $25,000 per year, working 80 hours per week, so paying taxes would have absolutely sucked. It's been quite some time since then, I've worked hard to get where I am, and for the first time, my salary is more than $100,000/year. Now: 4% of my income goes to taxes that fund Medicare, Medicaid, Chip, and health insurance marketplace subsidies (none of which benefit me personally). Another 4% went to taxes that fund social security (which LOL - I'll never see again.) ANOTHER 4% went to benefits for federal retirees and veterans, and social safety net programs. So fine -- I only gave about 1.0% of my pre-tax income to charity after all that. I donated, gladly, my time volunteering, but whatever if it doesn't have a dollar value attached to it, I guess.

After taxes, retirement savings, personal savings, rent, utilities, healthcare premiums, transit, blah blah blah, my disposable income is about $30,000 per year. Which, oh my god, is just awesome. For real! If you can't have a good life with $80/day to do whatever you want with, there's something wrong with you. I feel lucky.

I only mention all this because, while I consider myself a Democrat... it's just grown to sadden me a LOT to see how many people on the Left are such puppets of politicians that they have convinced themselves that "The rich don't pay their fair share" and say stuff like, "Oh look how ungenerous the rich people are." Fine, that's true for some super-rich people who have offshore bank accounts and make all their money through capital gains or the stock market or whatever, but that sure ain't me, and that I'm paying 15% of salary to taxes alone if of course WAY MORE THAN A FAIR SHARE. If politicians were honest, they would be saying that people who make more money pay more than their fair share because they can and it doesn't hurt their ability to subsist. I've been there -- with a salary of $25,000 per year, paying the tax rate I'm paying now would have cut me down to $20,000 per year Before my rent, my utilities, my healthcare, my transit. I sure as hell couldn't save any money at all, so I'm glad I'm very glad I didn't have to pay taxes. That's one of the reasons why I don't have a problem paying taxes now. If they go up, they go up. I'll still pay 'em, and no politician on the RIGHT will ever successfully buy me off with the offer of a tax cut. I'm not for sale.

All in all: hating on "rich" people en masse is an exercise in comfortable denial. My only problem is seeing how many people fall for it who fancy themselves enlightened and progressive. Nope -- you're just a tool of politicians.

These studies are being interpreted through a jaded lens. The implication is that these actions which are seemingly lower in "empathy" only deal with external reactions and not actual thought process, ignoring what the person actually thinks about before taking action. This also assume the actions we're calling less "empathetic" are bad or "worse" ascribing an arbitrary value to something. I don't slow down necessarily for people at crosswalks if I have right away because taking time to slow down if no one else is behind me costs both me and the person walking time instead of me just passing.

Also, as I'm seeing a lot of people comment on, people who start to gain power often have to learn how to balance empathy with practicality and guard themselves from those who would otherwise be dependent on them in a toxic manner. Yes often that means not engaging in people as often, or less or selective trust overall.

Hell the study about the "extra change" on the coffee is reliant on what people "say" they will do not how they will actually act. This study sounds flawed on expected behavior. People would lie to sound more moral.

Ultimately tho its just so focused on "Empathy" being this inherently good thing which is again ascribing a value to something it shouldn't be.

Alright alright, as a fellow poor person, I'll play devil's advocate.

1) Rich people cutting us off makes sense because they tend to have busier schedules like deadlines, quotas, and appointments they need to make. It's only the super rich who tend to have more leisure than their poor counterparts. Also people tend to get far more easily pissed at bad drivers than in real life. For example, if someone "cut you off" on the sidewalk, you'll probably say "Oh, excuse me" rather than "YOU F&%KING PIECE OF SH#T".

2) Returning the change also makes sense for the same reason. Rich people have busy schedules and can't always stop to do a virtuous act without accidentally being late to an important meeting. The personal cost for random acts of virtue is much higher for a rich person. Granted, since humans are ever adaptable, they then justify their actions by blaming it on the clerk rather than on themselves (i.e. "the cashier should learn to do their job correctly"). That's something everyone does, but rich people do it more often because the opportunity comes up more often.

3) As for looking at people, rich people have a lot on their mind, and their wealth is constantly sought after by those with less wealth. Ever been overwhelmed by too many beggars in a single day? That's a rich person's life ever single day.

4) Donating is a bit misleading because while they do give a smaller percentage, they also see their investments as doing good for society as well. Even though many wealthy people manipulate congress with their donations, many rich people fight back with their donations. Others invest in smaller businesses they believe in. None of these count as charity, but it's plenty for a rich person to feel like they are doing the right thing (whether it's actually more effective, I'll leave that up to you).

Don't get me wrong, I'm constantly ignored by rich people and treated like a second class citizen with my job. But we have to remind ourselves that they are humans doing what humans do. It's extremely easy for me to resent the rich, but it's hard for me to see them as people, and morality is often about doing what's hard.
